--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@r...> 
wrote:
> claudioillanes wrote:
> > 
> > Hi all,
> > 
> > I am new to JUnit and I've trying to combine a sequence of
> > testSuites. In one of my testXXX methods, I've tried to create a
> > TestSuite() (with a listing of  suite.addTest(new TestSuite
> > (XXX.class)) ) and I want this testSuite to run its set of tests
> > before this particular testXXX method completes. What I've tried 
is:
> > 
> > TestSuite packageSuite = new TestSuite();
> > packageSuite.addTest( OtherFile.suite() );
> > packageSuite.runTest(packageSuite, new TestResult());
> > 
> > Is this right?
> 
> No.
> 
> You appear to want to execute tests in a particular sequence; is 
that 
> correct? If so, simply add them in the desired sequence.
> 
> public static Test suite() {
>      TestSuite packageSuite = new TestSuite();
>      packageSuite.addTest( OtherFile.suite() );
>      packageSuite.addTest( new MyTestCase("testMethod") );
>      ...
>      return packageSuite;
> }
> 
> JUnit will do the rest.
> 
> Do not try to create suites at run time. Create the suite first, 
then 
> let JUnit run it.
> -- 
> J. B. Rainsberger,
> Diaspar Software Services



Ok, I see. The thing is basically that according to a number I get in 
one of the testXXX, I want to create an intermittent suite() that 
runs a set of tests n times.  For example, I am running test A, and 
in test A, I get a value 3 as the number of possible combinations to 
test. I then create a testSuite with a set of tests that will be run 
referencing data according to their assigned indexes 0, 1, 2 . 
(Representing three possible paths in the system to test). It may be 
possible to find these values ahead of time, but that would result in 
a tremendous increase in processing time, so I figured that if using 
an intermittent suite() is a possibility, why not do it?

BTW: thanks for the rapid response!!

Cheers!
